title: Leroy Sane's penny dropping is like a second big January buy for Manchester City, says Pep Guardiola
text:
Sport Leroy Sane's penny dropping is like a second big January buy for Manchester City, says Pep Guardiola Forward signed last summer got off to a slow start but has been showing in recent weeks why the Blues paid £37m for him Share Germany international Sane has the talent and workrate boss Guardiola wants (Photo: Getty) Share Get football updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Pep Guardiola has hailed the emergence of Leroy Sane as being like a new signing for resurgent Manchester City. 
Sane has been one of the Blues ' most consistent performers in recent weeks, as Guardiola’s side have moved up to second in the Premier League and closed to within eight points of leaders Chelsea. 
The 21-year-old German joined from Schalke in his homeland for £37million last summer, but Guardiola claimed his superb form since the turn of the year has made him more like a January window addition. 
Sane set up Raheem Sterling for the opener in City’s 2-0 win at Bournemouth on Monday and has three goals himself in his last six games, as well as contributing three assists. Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Pep faces the press after beating Bournemouth 2-0 Share this video Watch Next 
“The people say in the winter transfer window one guy arrived - Gabriel Jesus,” said Guardiola. “I think two arrived. 
“Leroy arrived a little bit scared. But, since the game against Arsenal [in mid-December, where he scored in a 2-1 City win], I think he made a click. 
“He showed us a lot of things. He is so fast, his intensity helps us a lot and he helps us defensively, too. And he’s only 21 years old. 
"I’m so happy for Manchester City, who will have a good player for the next few years.” 
The stats endorse Guardiola’s view. 
No City player has averaged more successful dribbles per 90 minutes than Sane, whose work-rate off the ball is equally impressive. Delighted Guardiola says that £37m now looks like money well spent (Photo: Reuters) Read More Gabriel Jesus opts for surgery on broken metatarsal suffered at Bournemouth 
He is top among their forwards for both ball recoveries (6.4 per 90 minutes) and tackles (2.2 per 90 minutes), making him an ideal candidate to carry out Guardiola’s high-pressing game. 
Sane also ranks top for sprints among Blues players this season, with 76 per 90 minutes — well clear of his team-mates and in the top 15 players in the whole Premier League. 
“That’s why we bought him,” said Guardiola. “He has a quality that is difficult to find. 
"Even without the ball, he’s getting better. 
“You don’t need to be a manager to realise his improvement - and it’s not just about his goals. He’s so aggressive when he doesn’t have it [the ball]. Sane didn't start a league match for his first two months as a City player (Photo: Getty) Read More We can come back and beat Chelsea to this title, says Manchester City's Toure 
"Hopefully he can be stable and keep going.” 
Guardiola places huge demands on his attackers, as star striker Sergio Aguero — who has started City’s last three games on the bench — has learned to his cost. 
It is not enough for forwards to simply score goals for Guardiola. They need to be able to recover possession, close down opponents and work just as hard without the ball as they do with it at their feet. 
That is why it is such a blow for the manager to lose Jesus for much of the rest of the season. The 19-year-old forward's tireless running off the ball is as significant for the manager as his goal-scoring ability. 
It is why Jesus had made the starting place his ahead of Aguero since arriving from Brazil last month, and why Sane has now made himself indispensable. Prolific Aguero will make way for a youthful City frontline featuring Sane before long (Photo: PA) Read More The five Man City youngsters who could fire Guardiola's men to future glory 
Sane, Jesus and 22-year-old Raheem Sterling represent the future of City’s attack, and are the reason why Aguero’s future beyond this season looks increasingly bleak. 
Former Manchester United and England right-back Gary Neville, now a pundit for Sky Sports, singled out Sane for praise in the wake of City’s Monday night win at Bournemouth, hailing the youngster as a star of the future. 
“Sane was my one to watch at Christmas, because I saw something in the Chelsea game, pre-Christmas, where he went on a run,” said Neville.
